docs.lead_paragraph: The aging of the baby-boom generation will have profound implications for consumer marketers, who are scrambling to adapt to the needs, tastes and attitudes of the boomers. Significant changes are expected in everything from the kinds of products on store shelves to the look and tone of ads. The companies most eagerly anticipating the coming wave of graying boomers are those selling goods and services to a preponderance of older users.

headline.main: OUTLOOK '96: THE ECONOMY: Middle Age Catches Up With the MeGeneration; Getting the Message To Aging Consumers

docs.lead_paragraph: Penny and Brad Osborne had no reason to worry that the baby they were expecting would have health problems. Still, when they heard that they could have blood from the baby's umbilical cord harvested, frozen and stored in case the child ever got sick and needed it, they leaped at the chance. "We looked at it as a kind of insurance policy," said Ms. Osborne, who lives in Cincinnati with her husband, a surgeon, and their son, Conner, born Aug. 7. "It costs $1,500 for the testing and harvesting and $95 a year for storage, and it's probably money thrown away. But gosh, if somewhere down the road Conner needed some type of therapy where this could be used, I'd hate to be in the position of saying, 'If only we had his umbilical cord blood.' And I guess we're hoping that as technology develops, they'll find more and more uses."

headline.main: Blood Banks Starting to Harvest Umbilical Cords
